By setting q>0𝑞0q>0, the accuracy of the worst 10% devices is increased at the cost of possibly decreasing the accuracy of the best 10% devices. While the average accuracy remains similar, the variance of the final accuracy distribution decreases significantly. We provide full results of other uniformity measurements (including variance) in Table 5, Appendix E.1, and show that q𝑞q-FFL encourages more uniform distributions under all metrics.

In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective q𝑞q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (Definition 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0𝑞0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0𝑞0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0𝑞0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, q𝑞q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average.
We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in Table 5 in the appendix, and show that q𝑞q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In Table 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

Choosing q𝑞q. As discussed in Section 3.3, a natural question is to determine how q𝑞q should be tuned in the q𝑞q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose q𝑞q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of q𝑞q’s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple q𝑞q’s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal q𝑞q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of q𝑞q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of q𝑞q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In this section, we show the efficiency of our proposed distributed solver, q𝑞q-FedAvg, by comparing Algorithm 2 with its non-local-updating baseline q𝑞q-FedSGD (Algorithm 1) to solve the same objective (same q>0𝑞0q>0 as in Table 1). At each communication round, we have each method perform the same amount of computation, with q𝑞q-FedAvg running one epoch of local updates on each selected device while q𝑞q-FedSGD runs gradient descent with the local training data. In Figure 4, q𝑞q-FedAvg converges faster than q𝑞q-FedSGD in terms of communication rounds in most cases due to its local updating scheme. The slower convergence of q𝑞q-FedAvg compared with q𝑞q-FedSGD on the synthetic dataset may be due to the fact that when local data distributions are highly heterogeneous, local updating schemes may allow local models to move too far away from the initial global model, potentially hurting convergence; see Figure 10 in Appendix E for more details.
We demonstrate the fairness of q𝑞q-FFL in Table 1 in terms of variance. Here, we report similar results in terms of other uniformity measures (the last two columns).

In Section 4.2, we show that q𝑞q-FFL leads to more fair accuracy distributions while maintaining approximately the same testing accuracies. Note that we report average testing accuracy with respect to all data points in Table 1. However, we observe similar results on average accuracy with respect to all devices between q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0 objectives, as shown in Table 7. This indicates that q𝑞q-FFL can reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution without sacrificing the average accuracy over devices or over data points.

Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. To study how data heterogeneity and the total number of devices affect unfairness in a more direct way, we investigate into a set of synthetic datasets where we can quantify the degree of heterogeneity. The results are shown in Table 10 below. We generate three synthetic datasets following the process described in Appendix D.1, but with different parameters to control heterogeneity. In particular, we generate an IID data— Synthetic (IID) by setting the same W𝑊W and b𝑏b on all devices and setting the samples xk∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑘𝒩01x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1) for any device k𝑘k. We instantiate two non-identically distributed datasets (Synthetic (1, 1) and Synthetic (2, 2)) from Synthetic (α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta) where uk∼𝒩​(0,α)similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑘𝒩0𝛼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha) and Bk∼𝒩​(0,β)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑘𝒩0𝛽B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). Recall that α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta allows to precisely manipulate the degree of heterogeneity with larger α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta values indicating more statistical heterogeneity. Therefore, from top to bottom in Table 10, data are more heterogeneous. For each dataset, we further create two variants with different number of participating devices. We see that as data become more heterogeneous and as the number of devices in the network increases, the accuracy distribution tends to be less uniform.

In Table 11, we show the accuracy distribution statistics of using a family of q𝑞q’s on synthetic data. Our objective and methods are not sensitive to any particular q𝑞q since all q>0𝑞0q>0 values can lead to more fair solutions compared with q=0𝑞0q=0. In our experiments in Section 4, we report the results using the q𝑞q values selected following the protocol described in Appendix D.2.3.

In these experiments, we explore a device-specific strategy for selecting q𝑞q in q𝑞q-FFL. We solve q𝑞q-FFL with q∈{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10}𝑞00.0010.010.112510q\in\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10\} in parallel. After training, each device selects the best resulting model based on the validation data and tests the performance of the model using the testing set. We report the results in terms of testing accuracy in Table 12. Interestingly, using this device-specific strategy the average accuracy in fact increases while the variance of accuracies is reduced, in comparison with q=0𝑞0q=0. We note that this strategy does induce more local computation and additional communication load at each round. However, it does not increase the number of communication rounds if run in parallel.

In order to be favorable to AFL, we use the two small, well-behaved datasets studied in (Mohri et al., 2019). q𝑞q-FFL (q>0)𝑞0(q>0) outperforms AFL on the worst testing accuracy of both datasets. The tunable parameter q𝑞q controls how much fairness we would like to achieve—larger q𝑞q induces less variance. Each accuracy is averaged across 5 runs with different random initializations.

Weighting devices adversarially. We further compare with AFL (Mohri et al., 2019), which is the only work we are aware of that aims to address fairness issues in federated learning. We implement a non-stochastic version of AFL where all devices are selected and updated each round, and perform grid search on the AFL hyperparameters, γwsubscript𝛾𝑤\gamma_{w} and γλsubscript𝛾𝜆\gamma_{\lambda}. In order to devise a setup that is as favorable to AFL as possible, we modify Algorithm 2 by sampling all devices and letting each of them run gradient descent at each round. We use the same small datasets (Adult (Blake, 1998) and subsampled Fashion MNIST (Xiao et al., 2017))
and the same logistic regression model as in Mohri et al. (2019). Full details of the implementation and hyperparameters (e.g., values of q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}) are provided in Appendix D.2.3. We note that, as opposed to AFL, q𝑞q-FFL is flexible depending on the amount of fairness desired, with larger q𝑞q leading to more accuracy uniformity.
As discussed, q𝑞q-FFL generalizes AFL in this regard, as AFL is equivalent to q𝑞q-FFL with a large enough q𝑞q.
In Table 2, we observe that q𝑞q-FFL can in fact achieve higher testing accuracy than AFL on the device with the worst performance (i.e., the problem that the AFL was designed to solve) with appropriate q𝑞q. This also indicates that q𝑞q-FFL obtains the most fair solutions in certain cases. We also observe that q𝑞q-FFL converges faster in terms of communication rounds compared with AFL to obtain similar performance (Appendix E), which we speculate is due to the non-smoothness of the AFL objective.

Note that in federated learning, we are dealing with costs and not utilities. Thus, max-min in resource allocation corresponds to min-max in our setting.
With this analogy, it is clear that in our proposed objective q𝑞q-FFL (2), the case where q=+∞𝑞q=+\infty corresponds to min-max fairness since it is optimizing for the worst-performing device, similar to what was proposed in Mohri et al. (2019). Also, q=0𝑞0q=0 corresponds to zero fairness, which reduces to the original FedAvg objective (1). In resource allocation problems, α𝛼\alpha can be tuned for trade-offs between fairness and system efficiency. In federated settings, q𝑞q can be tuned based on the desired level of fairness (e.g., desired variance of accuracy distributions) and other performance metrics such as the overall accuracy. For instance, in Table 2 in Section 4.3, we demonstrate on two datasets that as q𝑞q increases, the overall average accuracy decreases slightly while the worst accuracies are increased significantly and the variance of the accuracy distribution decreases.

In comparing q𝑞q-FedAvg’s efficiency with q𝑞q-FedSGD, we also tune a best learning rate for q𝑞q-FedSGD methods on q=0𝑞0q=0. For each comparison, we fix devices selected and mini-batch orders across all runs. We stop training when the training loss F​(w)𝐹𝑤F(w) does not decrease for 10 rounds. When running AFL methods, we search for a best γwsubscript𝛾𝑤\gamma_{w} and γλsubscript𝛾𝜆\gamma_{\lambda} such that AFL achieves the highest testing accuracy on the device with the highest loss within a fixed number of rounds. For Adult, we use γw=0.1subscript𝛾𝑤0.1\gamma_{w}=0.1 and γλ=0.1subscript𝛾𝜆0.1\gamma_{\lambda}=0.1; for Fashion MNIST, we use γw=0.001subscript𝛾𝑤0.001\gamma_{w}=0.001 and γλ=0.01subscript𝛾𝜆0.01\gamma_{\lambda}=0.01. We use the same γwsubscript𝛾𝑤\gamma_{w} as step-sizes for q𝑞q-FedAvg on Adult and Fashion MNIST. In Table 2, q1=0.01,q2=2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞10.01subscript𝑞22q_{1}=0.01,q_{2}=2 for q𝑞q-FFL on Adult and q1=5,q2=15formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞15subscript𝑞215q_{1}=5,q_{2}=15 for q𝑞q-FFL on Fashion MNIST. Similarly, the number of local epochs is fixed to 1 whenever we perform local updates.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Statistics of the accuracy distribution of personalized models using q𝑞q-MAML. The method with q=0𝑞0q=0 corresponds to MAML. Similarly, we see that the variance is reduced while the accuracy of the worst 10% devices is increased.
references:
To achieve this goal, we propose a new method, q𝑞q-MAML, by combining q𝑞q-FFL with the popular meta-learning method MAML (Finn et al., 2017). In particular, instead of updating the global model in the way described in MAML, we update the global parameters using the gradients of the q𝑞q-FFL objective 1q+1​Fkq+1​(w)1𝑞1superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑞1𝑤\frac{1}{q+1}F_{k}^{q+1}(w), with weights inferred from Lemma 3. Similarly, q𝑞q-MAML with q=0𝑞0q=0 reduces to MAML, and q𝑞q-MAML with q→∞→𝑞q\to\infty corresponds to MAML with a most ‘fair’ initialization and a potentially lower average accuracy. The detailed algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 4 in Appendix C.2. We sample 10 tasks at each round during meta-training, and train for 5 iterations of (mini-batch) SGD for personalization on meta-testing tasks. We report test accuracy of personalized models on the meta-testing tasks.
From Figure 5 and Table 3 above, we observe that q𝑞q-MAML is able to learn initializations which result in fairer personalized models with lower variance.

In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective q𝑞q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (Definition 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0𝑞0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0𝑞0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0𝑞0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, q𝑞q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average.
We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in Table 5 in the appendix, and show that q𝑞q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In Table 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0𝑞0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0𝑞0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. In our first experiments, we verify that the proposed objective q𝑞q-FFL leads to more fair solutions (Definition 1) for federated data. In Figure 2, we compare the final testing accuracy distributions of two objectives (q=0𝑞0q=0 and a tuned value of q>0𝑞0q>0) averaged across 5 random shuffles of each dataset. We observe that while the average testing accuracy remains fairly consistent, the objectives with q>0𝑞0q>0 result in more centered (i.e., fair) testing accuracy distributions with lower variance. In particular, while maintaining roughly the same average accuracy, q𝑞q-FFL reduces the variance of accuracies across all devices by 45% on average.
We further report the worst and best 10% testing accuracies and the variance of the final accuracy distributions in Table 1. Comparing q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0, we see that the average testing accuracy remains almost unchanged with the proposed objective despite significant reductions in variance. We report full results on all uniformity measurements (including variance) in Table 5 in the appendix, and show that q𝑞q-FFL encourages more uniform accuracies under other metrics as well. We observe similar results on training accuracy distributions in Figure 6 and Table 6, Appendix E. In Table 1, the average accuracy is with respect to all data points, not all devices; however, we observe similar results with respect to devices, as shown in Table 7, Appendix E.

In Section 4.2, we show that q𝑞q-FFL leads to more fair accuracy distributions while maintaining approximately the same testing accuracies. Note that we report average testing accuracy with respect to all data points in Table 1. However, we observe similar results on average accuracy with respect to all devices between q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0 objectives, as shown in Table 7. This indicates that q𝑞q-FFL can reduce the variance of the accuracy distribution without sacrificing the average accuracy over devices or over data points.

Weighting devices equally. We compare q𝑞q-FFL with uniform sampling schemes and report testing accuracy in Figure 3. A table with the final accuracies and three fairness metrics is given in the appendix in Table 9. While the ‘weighting each device equally’ heuristic tends to outperform our method in training accuracy distributions (Figure 7 and Table 8 in Appendix E), we see that our method produces more fair solutions in terms of testing accuracies. One explanation for this is that uniform sampling is a static method and can easily overfit to devices with very few data points, whereas
q𝑞q-FFL will put less weight on a device once its loss becomes small, potentially providing better generalization performance due to its dynamic nature.

In Figure 7 and Table 8, we show that in terms of training accuracies, the uniform sampling heuristic may outperform q𝑞q-FFL (as opposed to the testing accuracy results in Section 4). We suspect that this is because the uniform sampling baseline is a static method and is likely to overfit to those devices with few samples. In additional to Figure 3 in Section 4.3, we also report the average testing accuracy with respect to data points, best 10%, worst 10% accuracies, and the variance (along with two other uniformity measures) in Table 9.

A5.T9.caption: Table 9: More statistics showing more fair solutions induced by q𝑞q-FFL compared with the uniform sampling baseline in terms of test accuracies. Again, we observe that under q𝑞q-FFL, the testing accuracy of the worst 10% devices tends to increase compared with uniform sampling, and the variance of the final testing accuracies is smaller. Similarly, q𝑞q-FFL is also more fair than uniform sampling in terms of other uniformity metrics.

A5.T10.caption: Table 10: Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. For a fixed number of devices, as data heterogeneity increases from top to bottom, the accuracy distributions become less uniform (with larger variance) for both q=0𝑞0q=0 and q>0𝑞0q>0. Within each dataset, the decreasing number of devices results in a more uniform accuracy distribution. In all scenarios (except on IID data), setting q>0𝑞0q>0 helps to encourage more fair solutions.

references: Effects of data heterogeneity and the number of devices on unfairness. To study how data heterogeneity and the total number of devices affect unfairness in a more direct way, we investigate into a set of synthetic datasets where we can quantify the degree of heterogeneity. The results are shown in Table 10 below. We generate three synthetic datasets following the process described in Appendix D.1, but with different parameters to control heterogeneity. In particular, we generate an IID data— Synthetic (IID) by setting the same W𝑊W and b𝑏b on all devices and setting the samples xk∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑘𝒩01x_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1) for any device k𝑘k. We instantiate two non-identically distributed datasets (Synthetic (1, 1) and Synthetic (2, 2)) from Synthetic (α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta) where uk∼𝒩​(0,α)similar-tosubscript𝑢𝑘𝒩0𝛼u_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha) and Bk∼𝒩​(0,β)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑘𝒩0𝛽B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). Recall that α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta allows to precisely manipulate the degree of heterogeneity with larger α,β𝛼𝛽\alpha,\beta values indicating more statistical heterogeneity. Therefore, from top to bottom in Table 10, data are more heterogeneous. For each dataset, we further create two variants with different number of participating devices. We see that as data become more heterogeneous and as the number of devices in the network increases, the accuracy distribution tends to be less uniform.

A5.T11.caption: Table 11: Test accuracy statistics of using a family of q𝑞q’s on synthetic data. We show results with q𝑞q’s selected from our candidate set {0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10,15}0.0010.010.11251015\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10,15\}. q𝑞q-FFL allows for a more flexible trade-off between fairness and accuracy. A larger q𝑞q results in more fairness (smaller variance), but potentially lower accuracy. Similarly, a larger q𝑞q imposes more uniformity in terms of other metrics—(a) the cosine similarity/angle between the accuracy distribution and the all-ones vector 1, and (b) the KL divergence between the normalized accuracy 𝒂𝒂{\bm{a}} and a uniform distribution 𝒖𝒖{\bm{u}}.

Choosing q𝑞q. As discussed in Section 3.3, a natural question is to determine how q𝑞q should be tuned in the q𝑞q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose q𝑞q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of q𝑞q’s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple q𝑞q’s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal q𝑞q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of q𝑞q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of q𝑞q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In Table 11, we show the accuracy distribution statistics of using a family of q𝑞q’s on synthetic data. Our objective and methods are not sensitive to any particular q𝑞q since all q>0𝑞0q>0 values can lead to more fair solutions compared with q=0𝑞0q=0. In our experiments in Section 4, we report the results using the q𝑞q values selected following the protocol described in Appendix D.2.3.

A5.T12.caption: Table 12: Effects of running q𝑞q-FFL with several q𝑞q’s in parallel. We train multiple global models (corresponding to different q𝑞q’s) independently in the network. After the training finishes, each device picks up a best, device-specific model based on the performance (accuracy) on the validation data. While this adds additional local computation and more communication load per round, the device-specific strategy has the added benefit of increasing the accuracies of devices with the worst 10% accuracies and devices with the best 10% accuracies simultaneously. This strategy is built upon the proposed primitive Algorithm 2, and in practice, people can develop other heuristics to improve the performance (similar to what we explore here), based on the method of adaptively averaging model updates proposed in Algorithm 2.

Choosing q𝑞q. As discussed in Section 3.3, a natural question is to determine how q𝑞q should be tuned in the q𝑞q-FFL objective. Our framework is flexible in that it allows one to choose q𝑞q to tradeoff between fairness/uniformity and average accuracy. We empirically show that there are a family of q𝑞q’s that can result in variable levels of fairness (and accuracy) on synthetic data in Table 11, Appendix E.
In general, this value can be tuned based on the data/application at hand and the desired amount of fairness. Another reasonable approach in practice would be to run Algorithm 2 with multiple q𝑞q’s in parallel to obtain multiple final global models, and then select amongst these based on performance (e.g., accuracy) on the validation data.
Rather than using just one optimal q𝑞q for all devices, for example, each device could pick a device-specific model based on their validation data. We show additional performance improvements with this device-specific strategy in Table 12 in Appendix E. Finally, we note that one potential issue is that increasing the value of q𝑞q may slow the speed of convergence. However, for values of q𝑞q that result in more fair results on our datasets, we do not observe significant decrease in the convergence speed, as shown in Figure 8, Appendix E.

In these experiments, we explore a device-specific strategy for selecting q𝑞q in q𝑞q-FFL. We solve q𝑞q-FFL with q∈{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10}𝑞00.0010.010.112510q\in\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,5,10\} in parallel. After training, each device selects the best resulting model based on the validation data and tests the performance of the model using the testing set. We report the results in terms of testing accuracy in Table 12. Interestingly, using this device-specific strategy the average accuracy in fact increases while the variance of accuracies is reduced, in comparison with q=0𝑞0q=0. We note that this strategy does induce more local computation and additional communication load at each round. However, it does not increase the number of communication rounds if run in parallel.
